channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: The Week Ahead: March 29
item.description: Sports: The men’s and women’s college basketball tournaments roll on this week, and MLB’s Opening Day is Thursday. Jobs report: The Labor Department will drop employment numbers for March this Friday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 29
item.description: (NYT Magazine) Read: An excellent discussion on genomic sequencing.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Spain Holds Rock Concert for 5,000 People in Covid Test
item.description: The concert was a government-sanctioned test to determine whether events in controlled settings could restart again without contributing to the spread of the coronavirus. Zoom out: Organizers said it was the biggest commercial event held in Europe since the pandemic began.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Wall Street Mystery Swirls Over Massive Block Trades
item.description: A block trade is when huge amounts of shares trade hands, typically through negotiation outside of the open market to keep stock prices stable. Basically, what allegedly happened is that Archegos's lenders forced it to sell more than $20 billion worth of shares on Friday. In Saturday’s Brew, we noted that shares in Discovery and ViacomCBS had plunged on Friday following analyst downgrades.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Ever Given, the Ship Stuck in the Suez Canal, Has Been Partially Refloated
item.description: Bottom line: If the Ever Given can fully break free today and allow traffic to pass, the shipping industry can avoid the worst scarring, according to the NYT. You can get deep about it.  The Ever Given, a mind-bogglingly huge container ship that’s been blocking the Suez Canal for almost a week, holding up an estimated $9.6 billion in goods a day, is way less stuck than it used to be.   But that hasn’t stopped everyone from having a little fun at the ship’s expense—okay, a lot of fun. The moon.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Germany Avoids “Baby Bust” With Rising Birth Rates
item.description: This jump in births runs counter to the current and even pre-pandemic fertility rates in the rest of Europe, the US, and other wealthy nations: There will be 300,000 fewer births this year in the US, according to estimates. No one’s totally sure, but some economists are pointing to Kurzarbeit, Germany’s state-funded safety net.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 27
item.description: (Guernica)  Read: Your Saturday deep dive into the underworld of finch smuggling. The ship will probably remain stuck in the canal, blocking all traffic, until at least next week.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Dominion Voting Systems Files $1.6 Billion Lawsuit Against Fox News
item.description: And yesterday, lawyers for Dominion left the door open for going after individual Fox News broadcasters as well. Dominion Voting Systems ditched the Hawaiian shirt and khakis yesterday, instead filing a $1.6 billion lawsuit against Fox News.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Vaccine Tracker: March 27
item.description: At the current rate, the US would hit President Biden’s new goal of 200 million shots administered in his first 100 days. Moderna said earlier this month it had started testing its vaccine on kids.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: WeWork Is Going Public Via SPAC
item.description: Now, WeWork is back up to a respectable $9 billion valuation. , to make its debut in the public markets, which have been waiting for WeWork like a prom date at the bottom of the stairs since 2019.  CEO Sandeep Mathrani expects WeWork to turn a profit by the end of this year, following some belt-tightening measures he made last summer. Now, flexible office space is back in demand, and WeWork 2.0 provides just that. WeWork is going public.
item.author: Jamie Wilde
